But the question is whether they were also good teachers of their own virtue;—not whether there are, or have been, good men in this part of the world, but whether virtue can be taught, is the question which we have been discussing.

Now, do we mean to say that the good men of our own and of other times knew how to impart to others that virtue which they had themselves; or is virtue a thing incapable of being communicated or imparted by one man to another?
That is the question which I and Meno have been arguing.
Look at the matter in your own way:  Would you not admit that Themistocles was a good man?

502.speaker: ANYTUS
sentences: Certainly; no man better.

503.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And must not he then have been a good teacher, if any man ever was a good teacher, of his own virtue?

504.speaker: ANYTUS
sentences: Yes certainly,—if he wanted to be so.

505.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But would he not have wanted?
He would, at any rate, have desired to make his own son a good man and a gentleman; he could not have been jealous of him, or have intentionally abstained from imparting to him his own virtue.

Did you never hear that he made his son Cleophantus a famous horseman; and had him taught to stand upright on horseback and hurl a javelin, and to do many other marvellous things; and in anything which could be learned from a master he was well trained?
Have you not heard from our elders of him?

506.speaker: ANYTUS
sentences: I have.

507.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then no one could say that his son showed any want of capacity?

508.speaker: ANYTUS
sentences: Very likely not.

509.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But did any one, old or young, ever say in your hearing that Cleophantus, son of Themistocles, was a wise or good man, as his father was?

510.speaker: ANYTUS
sentences: I have certainly never heard any one say so.

511.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if virtue could have been taught, would his father Themistocles have sought to train him in these minor accomplishments, and allowed him who, as you must remember, was his own son, to be no better than his neighbours in those qualities in which he himself excelled?

512.speaker: ANYTUS
sentences: Indeed, indeed, I think not.

513.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Here was a teacher of virtue whom you admit to be among the best men of the past.
Let us take another,—Aristides, the son of Lysimachus:  would you not acknowledge that he was a good man?

514.speaker: ANYTUS
sentences: To be sure I should.

515.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And did not he train his son Lysimachus better than any other Athenian in all that could be done for him by the help of masters?
But what has been the result?
Is he a bit better than any other mortal?
He is an acquaintance of yours, and you see what he is like.
There is Pericles, again, magnificent in his wisdom; and he, as you are aware, had two sons, Paralus and Xanthippus.

516.speaker: ANYTUS
sentences: I know.

517.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And you know, also, that he taught them to be unrivalled horsemen, and had them trained in music and gymnastics and all sorts of arts—in these respects they were on a level with the best—and had he no wish to make good men of them?
Nay, he must have wished it.
But virtue, as I suspect, could not be taught.

And that you may not suppose the incompetent teachers to be only the meaner sort of Athenians and few in number, remember again that Thucydides had two sons, Melesias and Stephanus, whom, besides giving them a good education in other things, he trained in wrestling, and they were the best wrestlers in Athens:  one of them he committed to the care of Xanthias, and the other of Eudorus, who had the reputation of being the most celebrated wrestlers of that day.
Do you remember them?

518.speaker: ANYTUS
sentences: I have heard of them.

519.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Now, can there be a doubt that Thucydides, whose children were taught things for which he had to spend money, would have taught them to be good men, which would have cost him nothing, if virtue could have been taught?
Will you reply that he was a mean man, and had not many friends among the Athenians and allies?

Nay, but he was of a great family, and a man of influence at Athens and in all Hellas, and, if virtue could have been taught, he would have found out some Athenian or foreigner who would have made good men of his sons, if he could not himself spare the time from cares of state.
Once more, I suspect, friend Anytus, that virtue is not a thing which can be taught?

520.speaker: ANYTUS
sentences: Socrates, I think that you are too ready to speak evil of men:  and, if you will take my advice, I would recommend you to be careful.
Perhaps there is no city in which it is not easier to do men harm than to do them good, and this is certainly the case at Athens, as I believe that you know.

521.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: O Meno, think that Anytus is in a rage.
And he may well be in a rage, for he thinks, in the first place, that I am defaming these gentlemen; and in the second place, he is of opinion that he is one of them himself.
But some day he will know what is the meaning of defamation, and if he ever does, he will forgive me.
Meanwhile I will return to you, Meno; for I suppose that there are gentlemen in your region too?

522.speaker: MENO
sentences: Certainly there are.

523.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And are they willing to teach the young?
and do they profess to be teachers?
and do they agree that virtue is taught?

524.speaker: MENO
sentences: No indeed, Socrates, they are anything but agreed; you may hear them saying at one time that virtue can be taught, and then again the reverse.

525.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Can we call those teachers who do not acknowledge the possibility of their own vocation?

526.speaker: MENO
sentences: I think not, Socrates.

527.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And what do you think of these Sophists, who are the only professors?
Do they seem to you to be teachers of virtue?

528.speaker: MENO
sentences: I often wonder, Socrates, that Gorgias is never heard promising to teach virtue:  and when he hears others promising he only laughs at them; but he thinks that men should be taught to speak.

529.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then do you not think that the Sophists are teachers?

530.speaker: MENO
sentences: I cannot tell you, Socrates; like the rest of the world, I am in doubt, and sometimes I think that they are teachers and sometimes not.

531.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And are you aware that not you only and other politicians have doubts whether virtue can be taught or not, but that Theognis the poet says the very same thing?

532.speaker: MENO
sentences: Where does he say so?

533.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: In these elegiac verses (Theog.

'Eat and drink and sit with the mighty, and make yourself agreeable to them; for from the good you will learn what is good, but if you mix with the bad you will lose the intelligence which you already have.'
Do you observe that here he seems to imply that virtue can be taught?

536.speaker: MENO
sentences: Clearly.

537.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But in some other verses he shifts about and says (Theog.
'If understanding could be created and put into a man, then they' (who were able to perform this feat) 'would have obtained great rewards.'
And again:—
'Never would a bad son have sprung from a good sire, for he would have heard the voice of instruction; but not by teaching will you ever make a bad man into a good one.'
And this, as you may remark, is a contradiction of the other.

542.speaker: MENO
sentences: Clearly.

543.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And is there anything else of which the professors are affirmed not only not to be teachers of others, but to be ignorant themselves, and bad at the knowledge of that which they are professing to teach?
or is there anything about which even the acknowledged 'gentlemen' are sometimes saying that 'this thing can be taught,' and sometimes the opposite?
Can you say that they are teachers in any true sense whose ideas are in such confusion?

544.speaker: MENO
sentences: I should say, certainly not.

545.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But if neither the Sophists nor the gentlemen are teachers, clearly there can be no other teachers?

546.speaker: MENO
sentences: No.

547.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if there are no teachers, neither are there disciples?

548.speaker: MENO
sentences: Agreed.

549.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And we have admitted that a thing cannot be taught of which there are neither teachers nor disciples?

550.speaker: MENO
sentences: We have.

551.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And there are no teachers of virtue to be found anywhere?

552.speaker: MENO
sentences: There are not.

553.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if there are no teachers, neither are there scholars?

554.speaker: MENO
sentences: That, I think, is true.

555.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then virtue cannot be taught?

556.speaker: MENO
sentences: Not if we are right in our view.
But I cannot believe, Socrates, that there are no good men:  And if there are, how did they come into existence?

557.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I am afraid, Meno, that you and I are not good for much, and that Gorgias has been as poor an educator of you as Prodicus has been of me.
Certainly we shall have to look to ourselves, and try to find some one who will help in some way or other to improve us.

This I say, because I observe that in the previous discussion none of us remarked that right and good action is possible to man under other guidance than that of knowledge (episteme);—and indeed if this be denied, there is no seeing how there can be any good men at all.

558.speaker: MENO
sentences: How do you mean, Socrates?

559.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I mean that good men are necessarily useful or profitable.
Were we not right in admitting this?
It must be so.

560.speaker: MENO
sentences: Yes.

561.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And in supposing that they will be useful only if they are true guides to us of action—there we were also right?

562.speaker: MENO
sentences: Yes.

563.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But when we said that a man cannot be a good guide unless he have knowledge (phrhonesis), this we were wrong.

564.speaker: MENO
sentences: What do you mean by the word 'right'?

565.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I will explain.
If a man knew the way to Larisa, or anywhere else, and went to the place and led others thither, would he not be a right and good guide?

566.speaker: MENO
sentences: Certainly.

567.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And a person who had a right opinion about the way, but had never been and did not know, might be a good guide also, might he not?

568.speaker: MENO
sentences: Certainly.

569.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And while he has true opinion about that which the other knows, he will be just as good a guide if he thinks the truth, as he who knows the truth?

570.speaker: MENO
sentences: Exactly.

571.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then true opinion is as good a guide to correct action as knowledge; and that was the point which we omitted in our speculation about the nature of virtue, when we said that knowledge only is the guide of right action; whereas there is also right opinion.

572.speaker: MENO
sentences: True.

573.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then right opinion is not less useful than knowledge?

574.speaker: MENO
sentences: The difference, Socrates, is only that he who has knowledge will always be right; but he who has right opinion will sometimes be right, and sometimes not.

575.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: What do you mean?
Can he be wrong who has right opinion, so long as he has right opinion?

576.speaker: MENO
sentences: I admit the cogency of your argument, and therefore, Socrates, I wonder that knowledge should be preferred to right opinion—or why they should ever differ.

577.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And shall I explain this wonder to you?

578.speaker: MENO
sentences: Do tell me.

579.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: You would not wonder if you had ever observed the images of Daedalus (Compare Euthyphro); but perhaps you have not got them in your country?

580.speaker: MENO
sentences: What have they to do with the question?

581.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Because they require to be fastened in order to keep them, and if they are not fastened they will play truant and run away.

582.speaker: MENO
sentences: Well, what of that?

583.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I mean to say that they are not very valuable possessions if they are at liberty, for they will walk off like runaway slaves; but when fastened, they are of great value, for they are really beautiful works of art.

Now this is an illustration of the nature of true opinions:  while they abide with us they are beautiful and fruitful, but they run away out of the human soul, and do not remain long, and therefore they are not of much value until they are fastened by the tie of the cause; and this fastening of them, friend Meno, is recollection, as you and I have agreed to call it.
But when they are bound, in the first place, they have the nature of knowledge; and, in the second place, they are abiding.
And this is why knowledge is more honourable and excellent than true opinion, because fastened by a chain.

584.speaker: MENO
sentences: What you are saying, Socrates, seems to be very like the truth.

585.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I too speak rather in ignorance; I only conjecture.
And yet that knowledge differs from true opinion is no matter of conjecture with me.
There are not many things which I profess to know, but this is most certainly one of them.

586.speaker: MENO
sentences: Yes, Socrates; and you are quite right in saying so.

587.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And am I not also right in saying that true opinion leading the way perfects action quite as well as knowledge?

588.speaker: MENO
sentences: There again, Socrates, I think you are right.

589.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then right opinion is not a whit inferior to knowledge, or less useful in action; nor is the man who has right opinion inferior to him who has knowledge?

590.speaker: MENO
sentences: True.

591.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And surely the good man has been acknowledged by us to be useful?

592.speaker: MENO
sentences: Yes.

593.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Seeing then that men become good and useful to states, not only because they have knowledge, but because they have right opinion, and that neither knowledge nor right opinion is given to man by nature or acquired by him—(do you imagine either of them to be given by nature?

594.speaker: MENO
sentences: Not I.)

595.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then if they are not given by nature, neither are the good by nature good?

596.speaker: MENO
sentences: Certainly not.

597.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And nature being excluded, then came the question whether virtue is acquired by teaching?

598.speaker: MENO
sentences: Yes.

599.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: If virtue was wisdom (or knowledge), then, as we thought, it was taught?

600.speaker: MENO
sentences: Yes.

601.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if it was taught it was wisdom?

602.speaker: MENO
sentences: Certainly.

603.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And if there were teachers, it might be taught; and if there were no teachers, not?

604.speaker: MENO
sentences: True.

605.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But surely we acknowledged that there were no teachers of virtue?

606.speaker: MENO
sentences: Yes.

607.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then we acknowledged that it was not taught, and was not wisdom?

608.speaker: MENO
sentences: Certainly.

609.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And yet we admitted that it was a good?

610.speaker: MENO
sentences: Yes.

611.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the right guide is useful and good?

612.speaker: MENO
sentences: Certainly.

613.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the only right guides are knowledge and true opinion—these are the guides of man; for things which happen by chance are not under the guidance of man:  but the guides of man are true opinion and knowledge.

614.speaker: MENO
sentences: I think so too.

615.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But if virtue is not taught, neither is virtue knowledge.

616.speaker: MENO
sentences: Clearly not.

617.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then of two good and useful things, one, which is knowledge, has been set aside, and cannot be supposed to be our guide in political life.

618.speaker: MENO
sentences: I think not.

619.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And therefore not by any wisdom, and not because they were wise, did Themistocles and those others of whom Anytus spoke govern states.
This was the reason why they were unable to make others like themselves—because their virtue was not grounded on knowledge.

620.speaker: MENO
sentences: That is probably true, Socrates.

621.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: But if not by knowledge, the only alternative which remains is that statesmen must have guided states by right opinion, which is in politics what divination is in religion; for diviners and also prophets say many things truly, but they know not what they say.

622.speaker: MENO
sentences: So I believe.

623.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And may we not, Meno, truly call those men 'divine' who, having no understanding, yet succeed in many a grand deed and word?

624.speaker: MENO
sentences: Certainly.

625.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then we shall also be right in calling divine those whom we were just now speaking of as diviners and prophets, including the whole tribe of poets.
Yes, and statesmen above all may be said to be divine and illumined, being inspired and possessed of God, in which condition they say many grand things, not knowing what they say.

626.speaker: MENO
sentences: Yes.

627.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: And the women too, Meno, call good men divine—do they not?
and the Spartans, when they praise a good man, say 'that he is a divine man.'

628.speaker: MENO
sentences: And I think, Socrates, that they are right; although very likely our friend Anytus may take offence at the word.

629.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: I do not care; as for Anytus, there will be another opportunity of talking with him.
To sum up our enquiry—the result seems to be, if we are at all right in our view, that virtue is neither natural nor acquired, but an instinct given by God to the virtuous.
Nor is the instinct accompanied by reason, unless there may be supposed to be among statesmen some one who is capable of educating statesmen.

And if there be such an one, he may be said to be among the living what Homer says that Tiresias was among the dead, 'he alone has understanding; but the rest are flitting shades'; and he and his virtue in like manner will be a reality among shadows.

630.speaker: MENO
sentences: That is excellent, Socrates.

631.speaker: SOCRATES
sentences: Then, Meno, the conclusion is that virtue comes to the virtuous by the gift of God.
But we shall never know the certain truth until, before asking how virtue is given, we enquire into the actual nature of virtue.
I fear that I must go away, but do you, now that you are persuaded yourself, persuade our friend Anytus.
And do not let him be so exasperated; if you can conciliate him, you will have done good service to the Athenian people.
